floodArea.county: Leicestershire, Lincolnshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, Rutland, West Northamptonshire

items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Welland has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Welland, Medbourne Brook, Great Easton Brook, Eye Brook, River Chater, River Gwash

items.message: The risk of flooding from the Welland Tributaries has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

The risk of flooding from the River Witham in North Kesteven has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: On Wednesday, 16th March, heavy rain fell in the River Nene catchment. This caused the River Nene to rise and consequently this has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. The peak has now travelled past Thrapston and levels are rising around Oundle and Wansford on the bottom reach of the Middle Nene. There is no more rain forecast and no further flooding is expected, however, it will take a day or two for the levels to return to normal. We expect to remove this flood alert in the next 24-48 hours. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Sunday, 20th March, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are stable on the River Thame following heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is possible overnight (19/3/22) from Thame Bridge to Dorchester. The forecast is for a dry weekend.  
We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message tomorrow morning, 20/03/22, or as the situation changes. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are stable on the River Ray following heavy rainfalll. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads and land is possible overnight 19/03/22, especially in the Islip area. The forecast is for a dry weekend.  
We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message tomorrow morning, 20/03/22, or as the situation changes.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings.

On Wednesday, 16th March, heavy rain fell in the river Nene catchment area. This caused the rise in the river levels and the flow peak is now travelling through the Middle Nene, approaching the Lower Nene. This means levels are gradually rising on the Lower Nene, which will continue to cause flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river today, Saturday, 19th March onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties is not likely, however a flood warning for the North Bank Road is in force, as the high levels in the river coincide with high tides today and tomorrow (Sunday, 20th March) and will cause the road to flood leading to treacherous driving conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Sunday, 20th March, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: Heavy rain on Wednesday, 16th March has caused river levels to rise on the River Nene. During periods of high tide the river will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding at North Bank Road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible over high tide on Saturday evening and Sunday morning. High water at Teignmouth is at 19:45pm on Saturday evening and 08:00 on Sunday morning, times of high water will vary along the coast. Force 6 Easterly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 1.8m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required. Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Teignmouth is 1.98 mAOD on Saturday evening and 2.16 mAOD Sunday morning.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have remain high but are stabalising on the lower River Cherwell following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads and land is possible overnight 19/03/22, especially in the Thrupp and Kidlington area. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message tomorrow morning 20/03/22, or as the situation changes. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings.
